title: Ticket #6954: add regression tests for submit utils.
description:
Add a test that sends a variety of submit files / dictionaries to submit_utils and verifies the cluster and proc ads that are generated as a result.

In support of this test. A hidden argument will be added to the -dry-run option of condor_submit so that the cluster id used for the dry run can be specified. 

condor_submit -dry-run:cluster=<id> <ads-file> <submit-file>
will read from <submit-file> and generate cluster and proc ads and write them into <ads-file> using cluster id <id>. In this mode of operation condor_submit will assume the schedd is the same version as condor_submit, so that the test can be run without starting up a personal condor.

A new perl test called cmd_submit_regress_dry will be written to make use of this option. It will use a collection of submit files specified by cmd_submit_regress_dry.subs and verify the ads using information in cmd_submit_regress_dry.expect.

A similar python script will use these same files to test submit_utils through the python bindings.

This is intended to be a regression test, so that in the future changes/additions to the submit language, late materialization, and/or refactoring of submit_utils can be verified without a lot of new testing effort.

If possible, in the future we will compare the output of stable and development branches to insure that we don't break anything as we add new features.

Another new hidden argument will be added to condor_submit to support late materialization testing. 

-digest <digest-file>
will cause the submit digest to be written to <digest-file> in addition to being sent to the schedd. When used with -dry-run then the digest file will only be written to the file, and not sent to the schedd. This argument could be made public if users request it, but the RCFs have indicated that so far no-one has indicated an interest.
